App description:
Thumper is rhythm violence: classic rhythm-action, blistering speed, and brutal physicality. You are a space beetle. Brave the hellish void and confront a maniacal giant head from the future.

Scream down the endless track and crash through punishing obstacles with simple, airtight controls. Hurtle forward, master new moves, reach overwhelming velocities, and survive epic boss battles. Every crushing impact is interwoven with a pounding original soundtrack. To reach synesthetic bliss, you must go through rhythm hell.

* Nine levels of Rhythm Hell
* Adrenalizing Boss Battles
* Simple Controls: one stick and one button
* Psychedelic Visuals
* Original Soundtrack by Brian Gibson of noise-rock band Lightning Bolt

MinisterofDOOMJul 23 at 6:17 PM
One of the best - VR or not

Thumper is one of my all-time favorites. It's such a well-polished, superbly-executed concept with a perfect difficulty curve (after Chapter 2...) and among the most rewarding gameplay I've ever experienced.

I own Thumper on many platforms (including the Switch cartridge version) but I think on the Quest with my favorite headphones is the best theater yet for this experience. The 3D isn't world-changing in Thumper like it is in other genres, but it absolutely feels like a sensible step, and it makes the moving, breathing track feel even more visceral.

I particularly enjoy the new Play + mode, where the challenge/reward cycle gets cranked up even further than in normal Thumper, and where a single mistake feels SO much more impactful even that death, as the whole world slows back down to normal speed. Scaling speed with the multiplier means you have more incentive than just points to improve, and it creates a razor's-edge balance of skill and patience that adds another layer to the game's tension and atmosphere.

Thumper is among the most cathartic and relaxing experiences available on any type of screen. Absolutely a must-have for Quest, even if you've already got other versions.

Trying to describe Thumper with words, is like trying to describe how the we would perceive the world in 4th dimensions. It need to be experienced, so I advise you to just skip reading and get the game immediately.
Please take the above mentioned in consideration if you still want to read my attempt to write a review (Im concerned could do more harm than good).

Ok, Thumper is a very different kind of game- first emphasizing the feel and atmosphere. A combination of a dreamlike rhythmic trance, deep meditation and a state of flow, as the players visual input and motoric output eventually synchronize. Neurological reaction patterns, and muscle coordination eventually fuses as an unison mental interaction.
Without a doubt one of my favorite games and a must buy for all fans of the music and rhythm category. Many will probably miss this gem while browsing the catalog, as it is easy to get the impression that Thumper is monotonous and repetitive. If that is the case, I think is a pity for those who potentially, unknowingly have a game love lost.
Thumper is different. Without comparison with other games in the same "category", eg Beat Saber, Audica, Pistol Whip etc. Thumper is unique and must be experienced. Games like Audica (my favorite game on Quest btw) and Beat Saber have the following common features and factors, which in my case provide tremendous fun and entertainment value. First and foremost is the playability / gameplay / feeling and atmosphere. That you get a sense of mastery regardless of skill level, yet a huge movement in progression and along the way, challenged and rewarded with great sense of mastery.
Hence, competitive instinct is triggered, climbing the score boards. Thumper achieve to deliver all of this with great success - seemingly small in the shadow of its large and lavish audience favorites, but brilliantly and uniquely executed. And btw ... one of the few games to be enjoyed anywhere - sitting or lying down. A sore thumb is probably the only thing I've suffered from physical discomfort. A small price to pay when youve been steering a shiny beetle for 5-6 hours through an interdimensional Bobsleigh lane - at furious speed, pounding cosmic tribal orchestral musical mayhem, pumped with adrenaline in visually stunning, amazingly terrifying trippy dreamscapes. Love it - highly recommended.

As I've already bought Thumper for Steam and the Oculus Go, I was really, really torn whether to get it for the Quest or not. And I have to say: Yeah, buying it again, and this time for the full price, hurt a bit. But it was worth it.

Graphics are a little bit worse than the PCVR version, but not by far. But graphics are better than on the go, very fluid and a bit more detail/less aliasing. And the OLED screens do a very good job with this graphics style.

Gameplay is on par with PCVR, and out of the box way better than on the Go (no need for a gamepad, the touch controllers work very well).

In the end, the Quest Version is graphically almost on par with the PC version, has very good controlls without the need for an additional gamepad and it's a breeze to get into the game, just turn on the headset, don it, start up the game and you're good to go.

This is the definitive Version of this game!
